review_title: Enriching experience that helped me grow as a professional and person
pros:
+Empowers you and there is a sense of ownership while working 
+High on integrity and there is no room for any unethical behavior
+Meritocracy and performance rules
cons: - Sometime hirearchy driven though there is an ongoing attempt to be more inclusive and everything has its pluses and minuses

review_title: Great company to learn and develop your career
pros:
- A lot talent and incredibly smart people in senior management positions
- To my first point, there are a lot of good people to learn from and grow under
- Internal mobility options
- High investment in Technology
cons: - You can end up working long hours depending which team you land on.

review_title: no one will care about you/your development if you are with the corporate sector
pros: people are in general nice and helpful and would try best to help
cons: recent expansion reduced quality of people in general; corporate sector management from citi only trust those he hired from citi and ignore the people who have been with the firm for years - more bureaucratic than in the past

pros: Great support environment and a meritocracy. Opportunities are provided to talented to and deserving individuals and there is a strong culture to nurture and develop new talent. You are given big responsibilities early in your career and learning is promoted. Drive for innovation and efficiency is encouraged.
cons: Pay package lower than other market players. Pay rises may not be in line with market players.

review_title: A company worth working for, depending on your department..
pros: Good company wide benefits, HR department is great, Employee assistance program is beneficial, and there is a great sense of community. Looks great on your resume as well.
cons: Some departments can be terrible to work for, tough to monitor if every VP is effective or even manager worthy in this big company.

pros: Great training, organized, best technology.
cons: Too much movement (transferring), politics, sales pressure, job cuts, incentive cuts, work-life balance extinct.

pros:
Offers great exposure to finsncial domain with immense learning resources
Offers challenges each day
cons:
Org hierarchy keeps changing regularly with every change at the top level
Work is not organized - Could have been more streamlined for an org of this scale

pros: Some great co-workers, Jamie Dimon, some great opportunities if you are one of the chosen few.
cons: Bureaucracy and office politics are second to none and underneath the "culture and values" they really have no loyalty to employees.

pros: This firm is perfect for anyone who is looking to build their career in the financial industry. Although, a lot of people start here, then move on to other companies, only to come back here and get paid much more than before. There are lots of different opportunities within different LOB and the culture is different from one group to another.
cons: JPMC is not known to pay a lot, especially if you're just starting out.

review_title: Best place to learn lot. But u won't do what ur role state. End up doing all things.
pros: Learn lot about product. You need to smart to be in survival of fittest!  Is place is like race course, you will get lot of credit for good work.
cons: No work life balance. Only focus on productivity. No respect for people who are low productive. It's not me, that what i do it!!

pros: The benefits are great and vacation are great. 401k is the best around.
cons: Pay and career mobility are nearly impossible for someone that has been with the company 10+ years. No increases worth mentioning unless promoting into management.

review_title: Good place to work if you are interested to make a career in operations
pros:
- Structured
- Tight controls
- Company brand
- Global career
cons:
- Work life balance
- Limited mentorship across level that makes initial few months very stressful and difficult
- Nature of work is transactional

pros: Good Benefits. Training is valuable.
cons: Poor work/home life balance.  High Stress, Low salary relative to national market,  Morale in retail banking is poor due to high sales expections and low career advancement.

review_title: Competent Pay and Dynamic in approach.
pros: Good salary if you come from from investment bank backgroud. The first bonus includes welcome bonus and that could be twice as much as the bonus otherwise. Increment beats the inflation percentage.
cons: If you come from service industry you may not find your salary as competent. But they dfinitely pay a lot more than service instries.

pros: Great benefits.  Good support of professional development.  The local culture of best practice sharing makes working for Chase worth it.
cons: Culture of executive management blaming bottom level employees for problems.  In fighting between lines of businesses creating a CYB culture.

pros: Comp, Prestige, Work Quality, Co-Workers - all of these are definitely best on the street.
cons: Very competitive to get it in; extremely technically demanding; a little of instability early on with the spin-off but now basically the ideal bank to be working at (Goldman-size deals with the original Blackstone-level exit opps and culture).

pros:
-Great place to learn banking technology
-Management is very supportive of employees
-Good work life balance with management supportive of employees
-Access to top management
cons:
- might end up working on legacy technologies
- Some times the higher management decisions might not resonate employee thinking and be opaque

pros: Good exposure working with traders and other smart folks. Learn a lot about the trading life cycle, trades and client satisfaction doesn't just end after trade is done
cons: Hard to get own book moving into full fledge senior sales role unless others move on, role becoming more control focused than sales and business.

review_title: JPMorgan Financial Analyst Development Program - DE
pros: Great culture, and a lot of mobility opportunities. They also do a lot to show their employees how much they care. They are starting a lot of new initiatives, and kicked off employee appreciation week right after I started.
cons: The Delaware office has a much more laid back culture. If you are looking for New York style competition, then this is not the place to be. However, the people are great.

pros: Great company with many options to have as flexible of a schedule as possible.
cons: I personally was customer service rep for one of the credit cards, if sitting down at a desk all day while taking non-stop calls from customers doesn't seem like your thing, don't do it.

review_title: Stay Away from GTI Technology  - JPMC India
pros:
Brand  , Brand ..... nothing much , it add value to resume 
Canteen  - Subsidized food
New Faces every month  (Hire and Fire Policy)
cons:
No Work life balance .
Late night shifts and calls. 
Regular meetings and calls every day. half of the day goes on meetings and calls.

Too much of politics in GTI  -technology group , 
Appraisal are only a name sake game , performance is not looked on yearly accomplishment, it depends on  how much a person can influence a manager and be a  (hutch) dog who always follows them  ,those people  will be rated high for bonus and hike. 

They do lot of team building activities , without having a sense of people management. which is no use. They promote people who are favorable to managers during the events.Which obviously end up in frustration for other employees.

Bonus is just an eye wash during recruitment.HR provides fake promises to convince on package. People should not believe them when they join. 

GTI Technology is an Hire and Fire team , Once a person do not match up with bank  environment and  managers political game ,immediately on the face they will be insulted every day and cornered till they resign.

 If a person have good advertising and marketing skills they can survive here even though he/she lack technical skills. 

A persons technical competency is  secondary here , only process and procedures matters, you can win the game and survive for long if you adopt to process.When he/she leaves the company they will be blank on new technology , could not adopt to new tech in other companies.

Work and Projects are always short in nature , once the projects are over firing list will be prepared in each team. There is no shuffling and project movement or IJP. Just Hire and Fire rule. 

By end of 2018 , half of the IT professionals will be fired or lay off due to automation and robotics.Billions of dollars has been spent on automation ,so layoff is on higher side. 

IT Professionals who are lured by high package from JPMC should rethink of job safety also. They hire with higher package to attract talents , at the same speed they do not hesitate to fire anyone , even if a person is highly skilled and  adaptive to different technologies.
They should accept external talents and make them comfortable to environment. 
More than half of IT people in JPMC are in depression due to bad politics and inefficient managers.
But why do they work in JPMC even if they are depressed? - Reason behind is no one pays high package apart from JPMC or other banks for their profiles, they have to survive here till they are hired by some other banks  to pay loans and other commitments. 

Managers are 3rd class people , they are not trained on people management. These guys are in JPMC for many years without seeing outside environment . Cheap  behavior  and low class mentality. They do lot of micromanagement. They monitor on employees desktop screens and monitor the timings we  login and logout. Everything will be taken into performance management if they plan for negative review .But this rule is not applicable for manager lovers or followers(hutch dogs).
Moreover , for any issues , we can not approach HR , HR comes only on joining and exit.
All decision making on an employee are done by managers and Leads. They give open challenge to everyone  saying that nothing can be done if we decide on anything. A very open politics , no company can compete on this politics. 
Chances of bonus depends on managers feedback , if he likes a person bonus will be approved , if not no bonus or hike. 
I request all viewers to consider my feedback on GTI Technology , my feedback is just a beginning , more feedback's and reviews will follow after me from JPMC Technology division. 
A mass layoff planned in a silent way for IT Professionals in JPMC India ... Be alert  and safe
People who receive offers from JPMC rethink twice or thrice to join JPMC technology division.

pros: good salary and benefits. Company is technology-driven and demonstrates dedication to offering latest tools and technologies
cons:
Work-life balance is non-existent. Day-to-days is all about 'execution' and figuring out a way to get things done. Leadership does not pay much attention to its associate's needs, but rather mentality of 'get things done' any way possible. 
Communication is very poor, and leadership does not set a good example or tone for associates.

pros: Great coworkers and wonderful boss.
cons: Hours are terrible and no work life balance. The hours are from 8:15-630. You get to open or close but someone always calls in sick so you work both a lot. I always feel bad for the coworkers who have kids. They miss out on a lot of stuff for there kids. Not a kid/family work environment. If you are not working long hours they want you to do stuff after work. I don’t have time for that. It should be stance the law to have unpaid meetings for employees.

pros:
Lots of exposure. 
Always projects to work on.
Lots of brilliant people in technology.
cons:
Slow moving in terms of technology.
Red tape!!!
Whoever shouts the loudest quite often "wins"

review_title: An overall good company to work with
pros: Everything is good about working with JP Morgan. You have to be very clear about where you want to work and then JP is the best to work with.
cons: Everything depends upon what Management you'r working with, please make sure that the management with whom you'r working is really the one you idealized.  Very much process oriented and sometimes less focus on fundamental aspects. No formal training sessions are arranged.

review_title: Good Company but lot of politics
pros: Pay, Bonus, Tech exposure, Free transport, Sodexo
cons: This depends from project to project. Some senior people play a lot of politics instead of keeping the team motivated and show growth plan. There's favoritism, unappreciated work, bad behavior to name a few cons

pros: You have a job that will last for as long as you can take it,  Flexibility with work hours and vacation is granted because you've more than earned it.
cons: The pay is terrible and they work you to the bone, with no promise of raises or bonuses. And unless you are an Ivy Leaguer, you won't be able to advance to bigger and better.

review_title: Focusing on data management and quality wasn't started until approximately 2014
pros: Great people to work with & great benefits
cons: On the worker bee level it seems that things like tech applications, both home grown & 3rd party, are never well thought out so it changes often & without much notice.

review_title: A great place to work at
pros: The people around you are very humble and helping, the organisation turns you into an elite human once you enter.
cons: If you want to join, Gain experience and join a higher department. Lower dept. May frustrate you due to the goals set but over-all a very good experience if you join the higher hierarchy.. a better scope of growth as it want's you to grow

pros: Unbeatable variety - the opportunity to take on different roles with different teams. Once an employee decides to seek another role within the firm, no manager can stop the employee from leaving.
cons: General lack of training; also below average compensation - compared to peers, which makes it difficult to retain good quality, experienced staff.

pros: Sophisticated businesses; wide range of specialty areas; strong benefits package; ability to move across business areas; intelligent workforce; stable organization with steady leadership
cons: Business approach is very standardized; highly centralized decision-making; highly bureaucratic; long hours are expected and work/life balance can be poor

review_title: WaMu was a company who treated their employees well.
pros: There were plenty of opportunities for growth, both personally and professionally, the culture was outstanding, the employees were treated with respect and were appreciated.
cons: Salary is always going to be an issue. Promotional opportunities were plentiful but the salary increases for internal employees were limited.

pros:
1) Scale of everything done
2) Breadth of Financial services offered
3) Brilliant people
4) Stable in bad business environment
Overall a good place to work.
cons:
1) Pays slightly less than competitors
2) Work hours can get really bad. Can completely screw your work life balance

pros:
- If you are coming from a "Services" Kind of company, "No Swipe in/out" will excite you.
- Sudexho Card, Daily Ration of 45/60Rs.
- Transport/Cab Facility 
- Amazingly Talented people in US (Note: I mean people in USA, the people i dealt with in India were strictly Average)
- Lots of Domain training related to BFSI available for those who are interested.
cons:
- Local Middle Level Management: If you are coming from a "Services" company, you would usually expect a shift in the way people manage you. Don't. Most of the managers here are from the companies as you are and are no different. Their only motive is to get work from you, and disregard your concerns! 
- WorkLife Balance - They give you Laptops and say "You can now do Work from Home". Work from home actually means, you can login before office hours or after office hours from home. You have to be in office during normal working hours!
- WorkLife Balance - Most of the Tech Teams work from 12noon - XXpm time. There is no exception on this rule. US folks expect you to give them overlap, India Management expect you to give them overlap. If you have any issues, you have to move "quit". 
- Tech Work. - If you expect to build a Fast Trading Terminal using the best technology available, then this is certainly not the place for you. You will probably get "BAU" activities - Enhancements, L3 Fixes etc 80% of the time. Logically, this makes sense to the company, they save a lot of money compared to outsourcing. But bad for the Employee. You will end seeing CTS/TCS doing chunk  of the work and you maintaining them.
Most of the work is already done and you are expected to maintain it. They throw in a few "DEV" projects to keep you from complaining.
- Domain Learning : Atleast in my unit, my project, the learning experience was very minimal.  Whetever "Domain" knowledge i have is from my previous company. Theoritical knowledge you can get it from "Wiki"/Investopedia/Internal Portals etc - What you need in terms if practicals - you dont get. 
Salary - Being competitors of GS/BOA/etc you would expect to get a sack load. JP is not a Paymaster and is strictly average. Bonus, again is strictly average. There have been instances where you might get lesser bonus than you juniors! Suck it up and move on is the what management expect!
Onsite opportunities - Being a captive company, Opportunities does not exist. If you are lucky/unlucky you might get 2 weeks if US Manager Gods think you are worth it!

pros:
JP Morgan is the only company where environment is very very friendly, All the top managers are easly approachable no communication gap b/w top-down management.
Thank You
cons:
Transport facility can be improved to some extend as the company is doing well these days employee should get the benefited too.
Thank You

pros: Meritocracy, Career development, Learning curve, People Network, Compensation
cons: Bureaucracy, Office politics, Manager's incompetence

review_title: Interesting job with a good work life balance, despite what you may hear.
pros: Excellent colleagues, interesting work, good work life balance and reasonable compensation
cons: "Corporate" culture, too many non-jobs and a general desire to think about processes rather than the end goal. You have to fight for any pay rises or promotions over and above just doing a really good job.

review_title: My experience at JPMC was good and bad, it was very disorganized and I felt like a number but it paid well.
pros: The pros of working at JPMC is that there were resources available for me to perform my duties.
cons: The cons of working at JPMC are the chain of command was too involved and the ball often got dropped.

review_title: Great place to work if you're under good management.
pros: Great benefits including vacation time, 401K match, ESPP, retirement account funded by the company; excellent growth opportunity when you put your career in your own hands.
cons: Management varies significantly, the culture of Chase isn't created in all departments and issues don't seem to be resolved.  Repeat issues are brought up in the employee opinion surveys which the company is focused on, and aren't addressed at the top.

pros: Empowerment, competitive wages, flexibility, large corporation, great benefits, encouragement to stay healthy. Company legal trouble doesn't seem to have a direct effect on employees.
cons: Only room for advancement is with a different line of business or training. If you aren't in the "click" then its likely your hard work will be overlooked.

review_title: Nice place to work (lot of things depends upon team you are in)
pros:
- Good work life balance
- Good work, lot depends on team in which you work and importance of project to business
- Pay
cons:
- Things change too often, like team structure, applications are scrapped withing year coz of management change
- Many tools for doing 1 thing (lot of internal tools)
- No much focus on career growth

review_title: A company with too much politics, in a shrinking industry. Doesn't have a clear view and strategy to expand business.
pros: A good entry to the financial industry. Can get a lot of knowledge of how a financial institutions is run. Can work with very talented people.
cons: Too many politics. A lot of favoritism and if you cannot get into the inner circle made by the management, you should expect to be treated badly.

pros: Great Benefits, PTO and Training. The compensation is one of the best in the market right now. Seasoned professionals willing to help you at all times
cons: The length of time it take to get processes approved and the management of employees who do not perform well. They give them too many opportunities.

pros: Big name, big company, big problems to solve, travel to cool cities all around the world. Willing to  remove people who don't fit the mold.
cons: People love to do work without much thought for impact. Culture is very heavy on face time. Strongly anti-innovation. Poor pay raises punish anyone who stays loyal to the company. Very back-stabby.

pros: Great culture, experienced leadership team. Very co-ordinated execution of plans. Most of the employees know exactly what is expected out of them.
cons: Technology environment is constrained and even hawkish at times. There seems to be a disconnect between technology and business teams. There collaboration could be improved.

pros: This is a rotational program that hired me out of college. I spent 6 months in 4 different rotations. The rotations provided me with different experiences, lets you see different parts of the bank, varying management styles, and learn numerous skills.
cons: The process for finding a job after the program is difficult to navigate.

pros: It is a great place to work if you starting up in your career. Employee friendly policies. Good work life balance.
cons:
Everything gets driven from NY/London offices, so not many opportunities for senior folks. Most managers are in supervisory roles with nothing much to do
The day starts late and ends late to overlap with "primary" locations.

pros: It was a nice place to work while it lasted. Laid back for a bank. A victim of the financial crisis.
cons: It's closed now, shut down by the FDIC and then acquired by Chase. I was laid off with everyone else, so I'm not sure how Chase managed the transition.

pros:
Large firm, famous brand
Get to know difference divisions in a bank, different fields in finance
A lot of resources if you are a self-driven person
cons:
Limited mobility even if the company encourages it, be ware of your manager that cut your year end bonus to zero
Management doesn't care about people working under them, just try to use them as much as possible and take most of the bonus money into their own pocket

pros: Great work culture, work life balance, IJP opportunities, strong leaders as managers. Company transportation, Salary, hike and bonus, no micro management, listen to employee concerns,
cons: No negatives I can think of, I have worked for 5 years and employees concerns were rightly addressed and feedback is taken seriously and implemented.

pros: hours were good, nice office above pitt st mall, free coffee machine
cons: Sydney office - management was poor, no vision, no desire to improve. maybe just trying to stop their jobs moving to india and philippines.

pros: Flexible work options and continued training
cons: Lack of integrity by senior management is rather disturbing within this global financial leader. Senior management with characteristic of a bully while using sexual connotations in their everyday interactions with lower level staff. As if to 'dare' employees to report an incident. While open door policies and escalation are stressed, they often do not remain anonymous. With more than 15 years of dedication to the organization I find myself persuing opportunities outside.

pros:
- people are generally friendly and helpful.
- very deep bench at the senior management who understands the business and give vision in details. 
- given the size of the firm and HR strategy, great global mobility opportunities. 
- job security is better comparing to other wall st firms.
cons:
- $$ are not great comparing other wall st firms even comparing with European counterparts.
- the size of the company and its control needs sometime create bureaucracy.

pros: Daily Interaction with customers via phone, investigation, analysis and resolution of customer complaints.  Able to move to different departments.
cons: Money is not that great. Raises are very, very low.  Turnover is great. No bonuses. Employee recognition is very low as well.   Although moving up the ladder is very much accessible the money is not there making the desire to move up not desirable.

pros: Secure company. Very little sales pressure and heavier focus on customer service. Seemingly responsible with customer funds.
cons: Treats branch employees like lower-level employees--the company makes millions/billions in profit but it appears to go to upper-level management rather than trickling down to the branches.

pros:
Good company culture but few teams project management Is not good. They will treat employee as machine.you will not satisfied with your work because they will give you any work apart from your technology which you worked for long periods of time.
You need to flexible to work on any technology.
cons:
Need to improve rating system is worst so far. If your are not satisfied with your rating you will not raised any question against your manager.
Manager is your boss. Not HR friendly environment. They hire you and forgot.

review_title: Great place to learn and build network, micro management from certain departments was a big hinderance

Market leading custodian, ahead of competitors on certain areas

Rigid pay structure, no transparency provided

All decisions made by NY managers, especially around compensation

Micro management and no trust placed on people to get on with job

Very poor work life balance. Leaving at 7 is the norm

pros:
None
Terrible job, Terrible company. Avoid

You are treated like garbage by customers who say all sorts of vile things to you on the phone and you have no recourse and are forced to suffer the abuse. Management is clueless and won't do anything to help you. Worst job I ever had and that includes teenage retail and fast food jobs. review_title: Working in the Credit Card Call Center

pros: flexible, very good in using technology, conservative, do not touch it if it is not broken, smooth talk will definitely give you an edge.

review_title: They are new and slowly learning

Pay package is good.
Work life balance is good.
Managers do not make a fuss about leaves.
Transparency is there
cons:
If you want to work on latest technologies, this is not the place for you.
Appraisal system is based on perception

pros: Open door policy with upper management is nice.  Tasks being outsourced frequently and roles and responsibility change just as often. d
cons: I have had a hard time networking outside the IB roles.  The newark location for Financial Control makes it tough to contact middle/front office

pros: stable place to work; relatively good people; decent work / life balance.  Overall a good firm.

pros: There are a lot training opportunities. Doing first class in a first class way. People are ready to help each other.

pros:

Corporate investment on branding / commerical name recognition

Business units vary, however,  I found limited career advancement with a visible lack of diversity up the corporate ladder.
Overall, salary was substantially below the market (with very nominal raises).  My compensation doubled at a competing Bank for achieving the same goals/performance benchmarks.

review_title: Too few employees, too much work
pros: Good benefits and nice co workers.  Nice facility with good cafeteria.
cons: Corporate climate encourages 80+ hour workweeks and working employees to death.  Everyone works

pros: The recruiter was very honest about the job.  Everyone I work with is very bright in different ways, and I have learned a lot.
cons: Because the company is so large, the levels of management are palpable.  Getting things done can be very frustrating, but as long as you approach with the right outlook, it's a great place to learn key skills.

review_title: There a lot of redundancies that still need to be eliminated, hopefully some new management can work these out.
pros: There are many opportunies available and networking events.
cons: Due to the size of the company it can be overwhelming for new hires to get oriented on where to go for assistance within different departments.

review_title: I enjoy working at Chase, however I just wish there were more opportunities for advancement.

cons: Lack of opportunities for advancement.  You would think they would be plentiful in such a large company, but especially if you are someone who gained the majority of your experience outside of Chase, they don't value that as much as I would expect.

review_title: some good some bad it is what you make it
pros: good place to work some flexibility
cons: Never i mean never step down from a management or a leadership position. it will be like hell going back because even with your experience you will start right back from the bottom. you will be better off with a job offer with another company.

pros: The location of the office was great

pros: Benefits are good..Good transport and decent food..Decent Pay.
cons: Work life balance can be a challenge if roles and responsibilities of the job are not well defined and you end up doing everything in the project and there are no brownie points for it at the end..Management needs to have a better vision on where they need to put their efforts to achieve a strategic goal..Decision making is  slow in few projects

pros: Looked good on my resume. I was able to apply to other jobs and impress employees. Taught me the ins and outs of working in the finance industry...

cons: Politics. Retail management of the bank is quiet terrible. Without the right management, a branch will not succeed. Management tends to experience the "power" trip as oppose to helping their staff.

cons: Biggest con is constant threat of bank robbers, but corporate America can be cold and not understanding of some things in people's lives too.

pros: The company has always had great opportunities.  Those that work hard will have no trouble finding a career that suits them and pushes them to their highest potential.  Couldn't ask for more.

pros:
- Great integrity and professionalism
- Management is great and drives the organization well

cons: - Difficult to implement your own custom ideas and drive it at the firm wide level due to the large size of the organziation

cons: Constant changes mean that you have to be comfortable with fluidity. The bureaucracy can be challenging and the hours required to perform the job well aren't always the hours you come in expecting to work.

pros: Lot of opportunities to work in different teams. If you are good in your work your career will be taken care of by the management.
cons: Salaries paid are demotivating as compared to the amount of work that is expected

pros: The best part of my job is mobility and people. People are always willing to talk to you and help you achieve your career goals
cons: The bad part is the firm too big and things move slowly in the firm. You have to get through many people to get things done.

pros: JP Morgan is avery process oriented company. It has flexible working policy as well. While i was working fulltime i wanted to quit as i wanted to spend more time with my family but I was given a flexible Parttime work option by the company for a year which worked out beautifully for me and my family.
cons: Not all managers are friendly. So watchout which team you are going into.

pros: Good Benefits and nice to do for employee appreciation.
cons: lateral move instead of increases, Health insurance would prefer old way where you pay co pay of $20 at office visit instead of MRA.

pros: If you're going to work at a global bank, this is a top class company. Upper management is, for the most part, on point. It has a broad reach across many types of financial products, which is a unique selling point to clients.
cons: It's investment banking. It's not social work or medicine. You work your butt off on PowerPoint and Excel. Like every global firm, it has its share of politics and cynicism.

review_title: Great Place to Learn Grow and Woerk
pros:

Forced Rankings - You have to compete with your manager for your raise.  If he wants a raise / bonus - he just bumps you down on the list.
Year-end reviews are a joke.  It's not based on what you did for the year.  It's based on where upper management dictates you be put on the list.
No cost of living adjustments.
Lack of Management "Backbone".
first level management not allowed to staff up appropriately.  They scrape the bottom of the barrel for staff, consequently  morale falls throughout the teams.  SR. Engineers get upset that they cannot assume a basic level of knowledge among the operate staff.  Customers get upset because the operate staff is pointing them to all sorts of inaccurate resolutions.
To much infighting between teams.  
Considerable amount of time spent "reorganizing" and not enough time spent analyzing shortcomings.
Processes and procedures hard to follow or missing completely.

review_title: Too much of politics and buttering VP/manager
pros:
Cabs facility and security. 
Sodexo card and Cafe 
Relaxed morning timings (but there is no fixed time when you can leave the office)
cons:
1. If u can butter up your manager,then it's s best company to join. 
2. No fair process in the year end review
3. At the time of hiring, HR will paint a picture that you will be getting high bonus and benefits. In reality, it won't be even a single digits percentage of what mentioned at the hiring time.
4. Micromanagement and EDs note down the employee in/out time, lunch/snacks break duration. 
5. Anyone can give any review for you and you will need to explain it. Creates a unnecessary competition between peers and same level peers are asked to give the review anonymously. 
6. No work life balance. Working here is like you are a animal, and your manager can call you and ask you to work at 1am also. 
7. Just the maintenance work and nothing new to learn or to code. 
8. Even if the employee has met a serious accident, they would still expect the employee to come to office and work for them. Else they will take it out in your year end review. 
9. Managers don't have the guts to say anything about you in your face, but will go around and tell about you all bad and incorrect things in front of everyone when you are not around.
10. For India employees, the meetings are always scheduled at late night which are of comfortable time for other regions. The meeting timings should be equally well balanced for all the regions involved. 
11. Employee are expecting to not have any personal life even after working hours and weekends and can be asked to work on weekends (with no extra appreciation or benefits)

review_title: AVOID! Seriously. Just Avoid at All Costs.
pros:
Pay isn't bad
The office is clean
Location is nice and the building has a nice view
cons:
Oh where do we start? There we go:

- Hiring bar wasn't as high as I thought, so many disqualified and incompetent people join

- Horrible culture of fear! Everybody comes in earlier than the start time of the day and work hard, being quiet, with no interest to stand out, hoping they're not next

- Firing: They fire and layoff people left and right every couple of months and nobody knows the rationale behind it. In about a year more than 10 in my team had to leave this way.

- There's a hierarchy (Associate, VP, ED...etc.). You won't be respected by VP levels if you're an associate. Want them to listen? maybe if you become a VP too. If you're not based in NY, then forget it

- Extremely poor management in terms of decision making and the culture they create for the team

- Collaboration is ZERO. Only a couple of individuals make the "wrong" decisions

- Global team but isn't truly global. If you're not the US, you're considered a "helper".

- Bullying. Yes, outright bullying and if you complain, you'll get in trouble. They have a training that tells you to report this behaviour. But don't be stupid and do that, specially against those being the manager's favourites, because that's when you'll get in trouble (and probably fired like the others who did).

- They keep training employees on the "Culture of Respect", but you don't see this being applied by the managers. It's just a training that gets trashed at the end of the day.

- Team work is non-existent and not even encouraged

- Very little training budget. Surprisingly it's a big bank!

- The team is big, so exposure, interesting work and opportunities to learn are limited, and you focus on a tiny slice of the work assigned to the team.

review_title: Never forget it's a bank, not a technology company
job_title: Applications Support Lead in Glasgow, Scotland
pros:
The benefits package is good, lots of options for extra health, dental, ... coverage.

The offices in Glasgow are located right bang in the centre of the city - a great location. 

Vast majority of people are doing their best in difficult circumstances.

The volume of work is pretty low - see cons section for some comments on this but it does mean time pressure is not really a problem.

If you are a 20-something looking for a graduate job then it's likely a great career move.
cons:
I should say at outset that I had previously only wokred in science and technology, for around 20 years..

Starting as a VP at JPM I was simply amazed at the state of their technology. This is how technology used to be the in 1980s, they simply haven't moved forward.  so it's close to 20 years behind the technology curve, a ton of manual work.

The vast majority of the "technologists" have no significant background in real technology - mostly working (hard) up the greasy pole.  "Building their network" is most people's priority, meant in the making personal connections sense.

If you know what words like "socket", "latency":, or "character encoding" mean you will be massively in the minority. There are a zillion IT groups, each split into L1, L2, and L3, and   each responsinle for a minute sub-section of the overall IT landscape. My team was 25+ people. In previous environments that should have been a team of 4-6, but such a team would not wokr a JPM - the systems are simply not stable enough.

The whole place seems to work without any solution architects, so many "solutions" are not fit for purpose. A project owner typically leave a project once it reaches "operations", shortly after a farce of a process called "Permission to Operate" and a half-hearted KT session, and therefore there is no effective accountability.

Change Management is even worse.  Typially 50-100 people need to approve each change, so whoever initiated it is responsible for chasing people to click a button on a ITSM-tool, which of course most eventually do without even reading a word. Since there is no accountability it does not really matter, so its just a chore that slows an already slow system down even further.

I was there 5 months - in that period the onboarding process had not yet been completed. which sort of says it all. Everyone there for a long period of time is sort of used to it being as it is, and just accepts it. Tech savvy people dont hang around long - it's simply too frustrating.

pros: They have decent benefits, but not the best I've ever seen. You get 5% 401K match after 1st year, 4 months of maternity leave. VPs start with 20 PTO days. If you negotiate well for yourself, you can get a pretty competitive/decent base salary and a guaranteed year-end bonus.
cons: Almost everything. The company culture is trash - from what I have seen in their downtown buildings, it's full of eat-lunch-alone-at-your-desk types. People here are corporate drones that would rather send you an email from 10 feet away instead of coming over to speak to you. Technology-wise, working here feels like I stepped back into 1998. They don't issue laptops, so if you're in a board room trying to present something, good luck. You'll have to print out materials for everyone.  Instead of laptops, our desktop computers are ThinClient terminals, which run an operating system locally and carry flash memory rather than a hard disk. Since the ThinClient has no hard drive or local storage, all applications and data are stored on a central server. That central server sucks. I'm talking programs not responding on a regular basis. The lag was such a big problem that someone decided to disable peoples' ability to customize their desktop wallpaper because remembering all those wallpaper choices was slowing the system. We just have a black screen now. The list goes on: The emojis were disabled on Skype Business because they were deemed unprofessional. Having a Tech issue? You can't call a live human for help. You have to submit an electronic ticket and wait a solid 4-48 hours for someone to call you back, maybe. I have no idea how this place functions.  I won't be staying here long.

pros: Excellent culture, collaborative approach. Lot of respect for each other. Good work life balance. Generally one get rewarded for doing good work.

They rely on politics to be known and climb up the ladder. Think twice, coz these types of managers can cost your career in the long run, that is if you even have a career or just a source of living.

Management - Again, they employ policies that aren't necessarily because it will benefit your work, but they are just control freaks. Talk about micromanaging, yes, some have time to monitor every move you make as if its their main job. 

Management - How do they micromanage you? By treating you poorly like silent treatment, raising their voices just to slap you of their title, or even yell at you.  That's the truth.  It's as if the salary you get comes from their own pocket. 

Poor leaders. 

No career advancement / development can be attained here. You are so lucky if you are able to join a team that's lead by competent leaders.  But if its otherwise? pros:

review_title: It all depends on your team
pros:
AC bus facility for employee transport 
Free Sodexo meal card (as applicable)
Amazing infrastructure (including tech)
- this is one area where even some big companies falter but JP has it pat down - video phones on all desks, laptops + desktops and docking stations, teleconferencing bridge numbers for all managers, etc)
Employee engagement programs (Family day, year-end parties, events, etc)
Cash bonus 
No time tracking 
(Comparatively) good food but fewer options
Good employee medical insurance plans (self, family, parents)
20 vacation days + 12 sick leaves
Employee appreciation (RnR) but that apparently doesn’t get considered in the year-end appraisal
cons:
Company-specific:
No work from home option.
Cash bonus which ought to be performance based, is based on everything else apart from that. 
Way too many useless meetings. 
Loyalty to your VP/ED is more important than BAU - keep making them feel important 
Cab drop facility sucks. 
The seating infra doesn’t promote team culture; it’s kinda like call centres (everyone sitting in rows, instead of cubicles); makes collaboration difficult. 

The major reason for my bad experience is the team. I have seen colleagues from other teams who’ve been with JP for a long time (10+ years) and are satisfied. So it all depends on your luck. 
My (team-specific) list is as follows:
Bad colleagues who undermine you so that they look good in comparison
Management who only care about themselves and their image
Appraisals are based on the management’s perception rather than your work (sometimes of people who might’ve spoken to you maybe 2-3 times in the whole year)
Onshore management only care about getting their work done (even if you’re slogging in office for LONG hours)
Based on my above point - bad work life balance and frequent long hours: 12+)
Interview process is bogus. No technical interviews for tech positions (LOL). Anyone who the hiring manager likes can get in, with minimal to no skills.

review_title: If you NEED a job, then work at JPMorgan Chase. If you WANT a career then work elsewhere!!!
pros:
A great place to learn the basics & move on!  

Good benefits & stable company.
cons:
Stop allowing & enabling the Business Analyst management team in Commerce Solutions to treat their team unethically & unprofessionally.

The Business Analyst Management team is about 10-15 years behind the times and is immature and NOT professional.  They are more threatened by employees who actually contribute & add value vs. focusing on supporting, promoting & recognizing their team based on their contributions, qualifications & performance.  The Management team currently in place across their national locations (Salem NH, Tampa FL, Dallas TX & Wilmington DE) is only concerned about their “title” status & advancing themselves vs. truly supporting & managing their “team” which is done with blatant favoritism & unethical treatment of their team.  This type of treatment is promoted & supported by Human Resources and the Executive Management teams which is very inconsistent with their employee handbook.  While they have an organized Performance Evaluation process, all this is used for is for the management team to manage hard-working/loyal employees OUT of the Company who they are threatened by. 

I would NOT recommend this company to friends or other colleagues who are truly exploring career opportunities vs. looking for a place to work to earn a paycheck!

review_title: Branch Manager to a CPC-High Potential Branch.
pros: Decent vacation. Okay online training
cons: This is a comment made by a Market Director (MD) of Wealth, “Branch Managers are a dime a dozen, we don’t need them, we need good bankers”. Prepare to feel extremely undervalued. Your bankers will be the rockstars and will get all the credit by almost doing the bare minimum. Too many times I heard how perceptions are made early on by leadership and if you are not perfect you will build a bad image to your regional director which kind of destroys any future opportunities, unless you make your life your job and prove to them how you are their property. You are expendable, remember that.  As managers, you will spend 70-80% of your time as a teller or a banker, you will hardly do any managerial tasks like coaching, observations or huddles, but are still expected to do those and when you are not doing them you better gave a good excuse, and when you explain your good excuse (low staffing, technical problems), it will not matter to them and will still label you as incapable. It seems like there is some high level executive, consultant or analyst that fears their job is becoming irrelevant or is just bored, so they create new initiatives/programs/titles on a weekly or monthly basis and expect you to follow them, even though you’re still trying to roll last weeks roll-out. Expect to be extremely overwhelmed. They expect to be this cool advanced bank but fail to recognize that they are too BIG and can’t do everything that a smaller bank can do. They expect their employees to be these creative geniuses but can’t define which kind or what they should do to be these geniuses, example: this one Branch Manager provided incredible results and was moved to a flagship branch but when a high-level executive visited the branch and got to meet her for 1 hour, she said she was not “innovative” but when asked to explain on that she couldn’t even define. There is ZERO accountability for bankers, associate bankers or lead associate operations when it comes to controls, everything will be your fault, even if you had no relation to the issue, or you took appropriate actions or you coached to the issue, you will still be blamed. There’s a popular saying, “you don’t become a manager for the salary”, that’s because you’re paid on the low end. Your bankers will make more than you, especially the PCB. Promotions are partly based on your likeness, the perception you had on others or if you pissed one off. Everyone talks smack about each other, even your MD will talk about you and your employees to other managers (peers) and other MDs, it’s like high school. MDs have zero confidence on your ability to lead the profit of your branch. They’ll tell you that you have to manage it as your own business and be creative, once you do and report positive results, you will be told to do it the other way and how they want. Technology SUCKS, your ATM will break down,  systems will too, prepare to be embarrassed with clients and to receive bad surveys for that, oh and your MD won’t care for that reason. Staffing is terrible, and this is done on purpose, you will always be short-staffed just not according to a report. You will work 50-60hrs per week, even though they’ll tell you how much work life balance matters. If you are a High Potential branch, you will be part of sessions that are used to report, share and help but are really a pressure cooker of tension meant to intimidate, embarrass, corner and insult. It will be extremely awkward and uncomfortable during these High Potential meetings. They bring clients for money not for the relationship, once they get the client, they move on to the next one. You are running around putting out fires when your bankers are making 80-120k and don’t even care about the success of the branch, this company builds the most selfish individuals. Bad salary for amount of stress. HR recruiting is useless, you are expected to recruit your own people. Face to face training and virtual training are horrible, everything is high level stuff and niceties, no substance or material that will actually help you in your daily activities. You will be put with this training mentor and are supposed to be coached by them, that’s not going to happen, expect to learn everything on your own. You will not be trained on reporting that is necessary for your branch, but you are expected to know all of it by the time you are placed, if you don’t, you will be looked at as a bad investment, therefore, get with your mentor or look for someone to teach that to you, not your MD because she will think you don’t know anything. Everything is perceptions!

review_title: Hard to give a positive review of this company
pros:
Efficient, Smart, knowledgeable people. 
Decent Pay
Great Work/Life Balance
Wearing a suit here feels good.  

There are opportunities here - if you can find them.  If you are intern, you will see them, otherwise - good luck.  Even the talent reassignment guy has a difficult time reassigning people
cons:
With that being said, efficient/smart/knowledgeable people are hard to learn from.  Training is antiquated.  There is no program in place for veterans to succeed.  Networking across the company is futile and a waste.  

Minimal mobility.  You literally have to network like you're from another company to move across the company.  
You feel stuck.  Well.. you do, so... if you like this great.
Constant Re-Org.  Makes you wonder if your next.  They are cutting employees with 15+ years and giving interns great opportunities....hmmmm...  I'll let you make the call here.
Within 3 months of joining the company, 120 employees were cut, and hiring was made in cheaper offices in both OH and FL.  A sign of the times.
Managers will be on you if you try to better yourself using their training resources.
No Tuition assistance.  
No Professional Association membership assistance.
No break area
No Gym
No Bike Racks
High Turnover rate
One Size Fits all
You feel like you are chained to your desk and can't leave
If you have an opinion, don't say anything.  
Glass Ceiling - yep.
Managers are not leaders...they are managers of the information.  They are good communicators, but not leaders. 
Managers are all running around with their heads cut off because they can't trust the people they have or have hired.  It's gross.  It's insane.  If you want insane, come here.  I've seen stress...they literally produce their own here.  
Constant poaching from other companies willing to pay you more money.  That's sorta nice, but also a downside.  

The Culture and Values do not trickle down.  Sorry, they really do not.  

With all this being said, the company really tries to be better and some of the managers are so nice and down to earth that it's a chilling contrast from the day to day.  

Midtown is ideal because you can see and meet many others.... which seems to help you socialize and mobilize across the company.

review_title: The worst out of the credit banks only coming tie with BOA
pros:
The money was OK - BUT NOT great - depending what you did and how long you stayed in a position depended on your wage. You had to be lucky enough to get out of your department to move up in wages as it's very political and management gives their favorites the most money in their raise budget, I have seen it time & time again....

If you did not move around at best you could only expect 2% raise & I mean that is even if you had a quantitative job where you can prove you busted your back doing a great job.

Benefits do have Sallie Mae beat, in accrual of vacation in particular.
cons:
Constantly being challenged doing things that I felt was not good for the greater good of people, consumers. As a credit analyst the changing tide of how they want you to make decisions always changed and they were always looking for loopholes to get around roadblocks as new consumer laws kept coming up. 

It is very difficult to move to other departments and although it's a part of a manger's job there to actually coach you to go further, most can not be bothered. Often if you preform really well in your job, you are held back but given excuses that someone else better qualified for the job when in reality they were worse at the job they did and they wanted them out of there & wanted to keep you as is since you're a great performer.

Trust no one. Management is very cliquey and they often put people in management roles who do NOT want to be there so of course the direct hires suffer directly & indirectly.  They use antiquated software & hardware to save money of course. They use Avaya reporting which they know was WRONG yet still held reps to the standards on paper even though they were wrong. Same with phone log in stats; as a perfect performer I was told I was in AUX 2hrs+ a day, my job was threatened and I was told there was no way their reports were wrong. Lucky for me I knew someone who had access to their reporting and we proved that there was no way the figures added up right. Turned out their phones took my inbound talk time and made it seem I was off the phones. 

Credit was turned into a CUSTOMER SERVICE CHOP HOUSE which is NOT even appropriate. You should not be open NOR calling people on holidays. They used to have a great flex system where you could basically work your own hours...that was taken away and instead over time they added holidays as a part of a Credit Analyst shift... making any and all benefits to be in the position obsolete-- who wants to do white collar factory work and still have no good points?

Medical benefits horrible. Cost went way up, when I moved to a Medium sized company I actually did better in that as WELL as PTO time off earned. PTO benefits were ok at Chase but overall benefits can be found better at other places.
